resources:
Physics Data Review Formulas Explanation All Formulas Info
https://forms.gle/z9rQdiyYp2uz5MMo6 https://forms.gle/UvaUjvX2rmwffbd67 https://ko-fi.com/jayee
This app was created by an IB alumni to provide an easy to navigate study resource of the formulas in the physics data booklet. I am actively working on improving this app. If there is anything that can be improved submit them through the links below. If this app has helped you, consider supporting the creator. Report a bug → Submit a suggestion → Buy me a coffee →
//topic 1 ∆y = absolute uncertainty of y
∆a = absolute uncertainty of a
∆b = absolute uncertainty of b

Formulas for uncertainty calculation. A = vector
AH = horizontal component of vector
Av = vertical component of vector

Be aware of where the reference angle is and apply the suitable trigonometric identities. //topic 2 v = final velocity
u = initial velocity
a = acceleration
t = time elapsed
s = displacement

“Suvat” equations for uniform motion. Acceleration must be constant. F = resultant force
m = mass
a = acceleration

Newton’s 2nd law of motion, acceleration due to resultant force. Ff = Frictional force
µs = coefficient of static friction
µd = coefficient of dynamic friction
R = normal force

There is less frictional force for objects in motion. W = work
F = force
s = displacement

Used to calculate work done by applied force. Ek = kinetic energy
m = mass
v = velocity

Kinetic energy is the energy an object has due to its movement. Ep = (elastic) potential energy
k = spring constant
x = displacement of spring from equilibrium

Potential energy is the energy an object has due to its position. This formula can be used to calculate the elastic potential energy of a spring due to its displacement. Ep = (gravitational) potential energy 
m = mass
g = gravitational acceleration
h = height

Potential energy is the energy an object has due to its position. This formula can be used to calculate the gravitational potential energy of an object due to its height. power = work per unit time
F = force
v = velocity

Equation for calculating power using force and velocity. Ideal machines have 100% efficiency. Most real machines are not fully efficient. 

Efficiency cannot be greater than 100% p = momentum
m = mass
v = velocity

Momentum is always conserved in an isolated system. Conserved in both elastic and inelastic collisions. F = force
∆p = change in momentum
∆t = duration

Resultant force due to momentum. Ek = kinetic energy
p = momentum
m = mass

Calculation of kinetic energy using momentum. F = force
∆t = duration
∆p = change in momentum

Impulse is the change in momentum. //topic 3 Q = energy/heat
m = mass
c = specific heat capacity
∆T = change in temperature

Energy received/given in changing an object’s temperature. Change in temperature can be in either Celcius or Kelvin. Q = energy/heat
m = mass
L = specific latent heat

Energy received/given in changing an object’s phase. Temperature does not change. p = pressure
F = force
A = area

Pressure is a result of the force of gas molecules colliding with the container. n = number of moles
N = Number of atoms
NA = Avogadro’s constant (6.02 x 10^23) p = pressure
V = Volume
n = moles
R = gas constant (8.31)
T = temperature 

Ideal gas law. Ek = average kinetic energy per molecule of gas
kb = Boltzmann’s constant (1.38 x 10^-23)
T = temperature
R = Gas constant (8.31)
NA = Avogadro’s constant (6.02 x 10^23)

Average kinetic energy per molecule of gas. Remember to multiply by the number of molecules when finding total energy. //topic 4 T = period
f = frequency

Period is the time taken for a complete oscillation. c = velocity
f = frequency
λ = wavelength

For electromagnetic waves, c is the speed of light (3.00 x 10^8). I = intensity
A = amplitude
x = distance from source

Intensity of a wave’s radiation is proportional to the square of the amplitude (be careful when reading graphs). 

Intensity of a wave’s radiation is inversely proportional to the distance from the source, as it covers a spherical area. I = intensity
I0 = original intensity
θ = angle of polarizer relative to direction of polarized light.

Malus’ law, transmitted intensity of light incident on polarizer. If light is unpolarized then intensity is 50% of original intensity. n = index of refraction
θ = angle of incidence/refraction (from normal)
v = wave velocity

Snell’s law, refraction when a wave crosses between two media. s = fringe spacing (on screen)
λ = wavelength
D = distance to screen
d = slit spacing n = order of minimum/maximum (any integer)
λ = wavelength

Points of constructive interference have doubled amplitude (quadruple intensity).

Points of destructive interference have zero amplitude. //topic 5 I = current
q = charge
t = time

Current is the rate electric charge flows through a circuit. F = force 
k = Coulomb constant (8.99 x 10^9)
q = charge
r = separation distance

Force between two charges, r distance apart. Force is equal and opposite, obeys Newton's third law. k = Coulomb constant (8.99 x 10^9)
ε0 = permittivity of free space (8.85 x 10^-12)

Alternate representation of Coulomb constant. V = potential difference
W = work done
q = charge E = electric field strength
F = force
q = charge I = current
n = number of charges per unit volume
A = cross-sectional area
v = drift velocity
q = charge V = voltage / potential difference
I = current

Current is equal for resistors in series. Voltage is divided between resistors.

Voltage is equal for resistors in parallel. Current is divided. R = resistance
V = voltage
I = current
P = power Total resistance of a circuit with resistors in series. Total resistance of a circuit with resistors in parallel. ρ = resistivity
R = resistance
A = cross-sectional area
L = length

Rearrange to calculate resistance of a material. ε = EMF (electromotive force)
I = current
R = resistance (in circuit)
r = internal resistance (in battery)

EMF is the energy supplied per coulomb of charge. ε is equal to V when no current is flowing. F = force
q = charge
v = velocity of charge
B = magnitude of magnetic field
θ = angle with field

Force on a charge moving through a magnetic field. F = force
B = magnitude of magnetic field
I = current
L = length of wire
θ = angle with field

Force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field. //topic 6 v = velocity
ω = angular velocity
r = radius of circle

Velocity of a body traveling in a circle. a = acceleration
v = velocity
r = radius of circle
T = period

Calculation of centripetal acceleration. F = force
m = mass
v = velocity
r = radius of circle
ω = angular velocity

Calculation of centripetal force. Centripetal force is always towards the center and perpendicular to the direction of velocity. F = force 
G = gravitational constant (6.67 x 10^-11)
M = mass of first body
m = mass of second body 
r = radius

Newton’s law of gravitation. Force experienced by 2 masses. Force on each mass is equal and opposite. g = gravitational field strength
F = force
m = mass
Field strength as experienced by mass in field.

G = gravitational constant (6.67 x 10^-11)
M = mass of first body
r = radius
Field strength at a certain distance from a body. //topic 7 E = energy
h = planck’s constant (6.63 x 10^-34)
f = frequency
λ = wavelength
c = speed of light (3.00 x 10^8)

Formulas for calculating the energy and wavelength of a photon. E = energy
m = mass
c = speed of light (3.00 x 10^8)

Einstein’s theory of relativity of mass energy equivalence. Loss in mass -> energy. To calculate energy released in a reaction, find mass difference and use formula. u = up, d = down, c = charm, s = strange, t = top, b = bottom

All quarks have an antiquark with opposite charge and -⅓ baryon number. 

Mesons are made up of one quark and one antiquark with a baryon number of 0. Baryons are made up of three quarks with a baryon number of 1.

Protons: uud
Neutrons: udd e = electron
μ = muon
τ = tau 
v = neutrino

Family lepton number is always conserved. Strangeness is not conserved in weak interactions.

If a charged particle is produced through an interaction, use an exchange particle with the charge of the particle. //topic 8 Power is the work done per unit time. A = area swept out by turbine blades = πL^2 where L is the length of the blade
ρ = air density
v = wind speed

Calculate power produced by an ideal wind turbine. Real wind turbine would produce less power as air does not come to rest inside the turbine and some energy is lost as heat. P = power
e = emissivity (1 for black body)
σ = Stefan-Boltzmann constant (1.38 x 10^-23)
T = temperature

Calculate the power radiated by a body. λ = wavelength
T = temperature.

Wavelength at which intensity is at a maximum. I = intensity
A = area

Calculate intensity of radiation, power per unit area. Albedo is the ratio between the total scattered (reflected) radiation and the total incident radiation of that planet. //topic 9 ω = angular frequency
T = period

Relationship between angular frequency and period of oscillation. a = acceleration
ω = angular frequency
x = displacement from equilibrium

Acceleration of an object in SHM is proportional and opposite to displacement. x = displacement from equilibrium
v = velocity
x0 = maximum displacement
ω = angular frequency
t = time elapsed

For displacement use sin function if object starts at zero displacement, use cos if object starts at maximum displacement. Use the other function for velocity. v = velocity
x = displacement from equilibrium
x0 = maximum displacement
ω = angular frequency

Velocity of object in SHM. Ek = Kinetic energy
ET = Total energy
m = mass
ω = angular frequency
x = displacement from equilibrium
x0 = maximum displacement

Energy of an object in SHM. Total energy is constant (energy converted between potential and kinetic). T = period
l = length of pendulum
g = gravitational field strength
m = mass
k = spring constant

Calculation of period of oscillation for pendulum and mass-spring system. θ = angle
λ = wavelength
b = slit width

Calculation of the angle at which the first minimum occurs in single-slit diffraction. n = order (any integer)
λ = wavelength
d = slit spacing 
θ = angle

Calculate path difference between slits for diffraction grating. d = thickness of medium
n = refractive index
m = any integer
λ = wavelength

Constructive or destructive interference for thin film interference with one phase shift. If two or no phase shifts then constructive and destructive interference are reversed. θ = angle between two objects
λ = wavelength
b = slit width / diameter of lens

Minimum angle for two objects to be resolved. Use trigonometry to find minimum distance from the observer or minimum distance between objects. R = resolvance
λ = wavelength / average between two wavelength
Δλ = smallest resolvable wavelength difference
m = diffraction order
N = number of slits illuminated

Resolvance of a diffraction grating. f’ = perceived frequency
f = actual / emitted frequency
v = wave speed
us = velocity of source
uo = velocity of observer

Doppler effect equations. Perceived frequency is greater if the observer/source is moving towards the other. Perceived frequency is smaller if the observer/source is moving away from the other. f = frequency
λ = wavelength
v = relative speed of observer and source
c = speed of light

Doppler effect for light. //topic 10 W = work
q = charge
m = mass
Ve = electric potential
Vg = gravitational potential

Work done moving a charge/mass between 2 points in a field. Vg = gravitational potential
Ve = electric potential
G = gravitational constant (6.67 x 10^-11)
k = coulomb constant (8.99 x 10^9)
M = mass
Q = charge
r = separation distance

Gravitational/electric potential is the work done per unit mass bringing a small point mass/charge in from infinity to a point in a gravitational field. g = gravitational field strength
E = electric field strength
Vg = gravitational potential
Ve = electric potential
r = separation distance

Gravitational/electric field strength is the force per unit mass exerted on a small or point mass/charge. Ep = potential energy
Vg = gravitational potential
Ve = electric potential
G = gravitational constant (6.67 x 10^-11)
k = coulomb constant (8.99 x 10^9)
m = mass 1
M = mass 2
q = charge 1 
Q = charge 2

Gravitational/electric potential energy is the work done bringing a small point mass/charge in from infinity to a point in a gravitational field. Fg = gravitational force
Fe = electric force
G = gravitational constant (6.67 x 10^-11)
k = coulomb constant (8.99 x 10^9)
m = mass 1 
M = mass 2
q = charge 1
Q = charge 2
r = separation distance

Force experienced by 2 masses/charges. Force on each mass/charge is equal and opposite. v(esc) = escape velocity of a planet
v(orbit) = velocity of a body in circular orbit around another body
G = gravitational constant (6.67 x 10^-11)
M = mass 2
r = separation distance //topic 11 Φ = magnetic flux
B = magnitude of magnetic field
A = area of coil in field
θ = angle from normal of the field ε = induced emf
N = number of turns in coil
Φ = magnetic flux
t = time elapsed

Faraday’s law: emf induced is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux. 

Lenz’s law: The direction of an induced emf is such that it produces a magnetic field whose direction opposes the change in magnetic field that produced it. ε = induced emf
B = magnitude of magnetic field
v = speed of wire
l = length of wire
N = number of turns in coil

Induced emf in a conductor moving through a field. I(rms) = effective current
V(rms) = effective voltage
I0 = maximum current
V0 = maximum voltage
R = resistance

Root mean square (rms) values for alternating current is equal to the value of constant direct current that would produce the same power dissipation in a resistive load. P(max) = maximum power dissipated
P̄ = average power dissipated
I0 = maximum current
V0 = maximum voltage. ε = emf
N = number of turns
I = current
p=primary 
s= secondary 

Ratio of emf, turns and current in a transformer. C = capacitance
q = charge
V = voltage

Capacitance of a capacitor C = capacitance

Capacitance of capacitors in parallel, is the sum of individual capacitors. C = capacitance

The reciprocal of capacitance of capacitors in series is the sum of the reciprocals of the individual capacitors. C = capacitance
ε = permittivity of dielectric material
A = area of plates
d = separation of plates

Capacitance of a capacitor. In air use permittivity of free space (8.85 x 10^-12). E = energy stored
C = capacitance
V = voltage

Energy stored in a capacitor. τ = time constant
R = resistance
C = capacitance

q=charge
q0 = original charge
I = current
I0 = initial maximum current
V = voltage
V0 = initial maximum voltage

t=time elapsed

Formulas for the exponential decrease of charge/current/voltage of a discharging capacitor. //topic 12 E = energy
h = planck’s constant (6.63 x 10^-34)
f = frequency

Formulas for calculating the energy of a photon. E(max) = maximum energy of freed electron
h = planck’s constant (6.63 x 10^-34)
f = frequency
Φ = work function

Formula for calculating the kinetic energy of a freed electron due to the photoelectric effect. E = energy
n = energy level

Quantised energy of an electron in the hydrogen atom. m = mass
v = velocity
r = radius
n = energy level
h = planck’s constant (6.63 x 10^-34)

Angular momentum of the orbiting electron in the hydrogen atom. P(r) = probability that an electron will be found within a small volume
Ψ = wave function
V = volume

Schrodinger’s equation, electrons in the atom may be described by wavefunctions. The electron has an undefined position, but the square of the amplitude of the wavefunction gives the probability of finding the electron at a particular point. x = position
p = momentum
E = energy
t = time
h = planck’s constant (6.63 x 10^-34)

Heisenberg’s uncertainty principles, conjugate quantities (position-momentum or time-energy) cannot be known precisely at the same time. R = Nuclear radius
R0 = fermi radius (1.20 x 10^-15)
A = Atomic mass number

Nuclear radius of an element. The density of the nucleus for all elements is approximately the same. N = number of nuclei
A = activity
N0 = original number of nuclei
t = time elapsed
λ = decay constant = ln(2)/half-life

Formulas for calculating the number of remaining nuclei/activity in a radioactive sample. θ = angle of first minimum
λ = De Broglie wavelength
D = diameter of circular object

First minimum of an electron diffraction pattern around a circular object.
